metadata.description: AviLingo Seed Content Database - Vocabulary, Listening, Speaking

vocabulary.definition: Yes, that is correct. Used instead of 'yes' in radiotelephony.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Standard ICAO phraseology for confirming a statement or request.
vocabulary.example_atc: Speedbird 123, confirm you are ready for departure?
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: Stress on second syllable: af-FIRM, not AF-firm

vocabulary.definition: No, that is not correct. Permission not granted.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Standard ICAO phraseology for denying or correcting.
vocabulary.example_atc: Delta 456, are you able to accept runway 28L?
vocabulary.example_response: Negative, Delta 456, we need runway 28R due to aircraft performance.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: NEG-uh-tiv, three syllables. Don't drop the middle syllable.

vocabulary.definition: I have received all of your last transmission. Does NOT mean 'yes' or 'I will comply'.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Acknowledgment of receipt only. Never use in response to a question requiring yes/no.
vocabulary.example_atc: United 789, the weather at destination is deteriorating.
common_errors: Using 'roger' to mean 'yes' or 'I will comply'
Using 'roger' in response to a clearance (should use readback)
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: ROJ-er, soft 'g' sound like 'j'. Not 'ROG-er' with hard 'g'.

vocabulary.definition: I understand your message and will comply with it. Short for 'will comply'.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Use when acknowledging an instruction you will follow. Includes 'roger' so don't say both.
vocabulary.example_atc: Lufthansa 450, after departure turn left heading 270.
common_errors: Using wilco without intending to comply

vocabulary.definition: Repeat all or the following part of your last transmission.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Standard request for repetition. Never use 'repeat' which has a different military meaning.
vocabulary.example_atc: Mumbai Control, Air India 505, say again the cleared level.
vocabulary.example_response: Air India 505, climb and maintain flight level 350.
common_errors: Not specifying which part to repeat
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: Clear 'th' sound in 'the' if using 'say again the...'

vocabulary.definition: Wait and I will call you. No answer is expected.
vocabulary.aviation_context: ATC uses when busy. Pilot should wait without further transmission.
vocabulary.example_atc: Emirates 202, standby.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: STAND-by, not 'stand-BY'. Stress on first syllable.

vocabulary.definition: I cannot comply with your request or instruction.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Pilot refusal of ATC instruction. Should always provide reason.
vocabulary.example_atc: Aeroflot 215, descend to 3000 feet.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: un-AY-bl, stress on second syllable. The 'a' is a long 'ay' sound.

vocabulary.definition: Authorized to proceed under the conditions specified.
vocabulary.aviation_context: ATC authorization. Critical word - must be in every clearance.
vocabulary.example_atc: Turkish 301, cleared for takeoff runway 05.
common_errors: Confusing 'cleared for takeoff' with 'cleared to land'

vocabulary.definition: A maneuver where the pilot aborts landing and climbs away from the runway.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Commanded by ATC or initiated by pilot when landing is unsafe.
vocabulary.example_atc: United 472, go around, traffic on runway.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: GO-uh-round. The 'ow' in 'around' is a diphthong, not flat 'o'.

vocabulary.definition: Stop before reaching a specified point (usually runway).
vocabulary.aviation_context: Critical ground movement instruction. Requires readback.
vocabulary.example_atc: Cathay 880, hold short of runway 25L.
common_errors: Not reading back hold short instructions
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: HOHLD SHORT. The 'o' in 'hold' is long 'oh'. Clear 'sh' sound.

vocabulary.definition: Enter the runway and wait for takeoff clearance.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Formerly 'position and hold' in US. Does NOT authorize takeoff.
vocabulary.example_atc: Air France 692, runway 27, line up and wait.
vocabulary.example_response: Runway 27, line up and wait, Air France 692.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: LINE up, not 'LIN up'. Long 'i' sound.

vocabulary.definition: Select the specified transponder code.
vocabulary.aviation_context: ATC assigns 4-digit code for identification on radar.
vocabulary.example_atc: KLM 605, squawk 4521.
common_errors: Not setting transponder to correct mode
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: SKWAWK. The 'qu' makes a 'kw' sound, not 'sk'.

vocabulary.definition: International distress signal indicating grave and imminent danger requiring immediate assistance.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Highest priority emergency. Said three times: 'Mayday, Mayday, Mayday.'
vocabulary.example_atc: Mayday, Mayday, Mayday. Speedbird 38 heavy, engine fire, returning to London.
common_errors: Using for non-life-threatening situations (should use Pan-Pan)
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: MAY-day, stress on first syllable. Clear 'ay' diphthong.

vocabulary.definition: International urgency signal indicating a condition concerning safety but not immediate danger.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Second priority after Mayday. Said three times for urgency.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan. ABC123, medical emergency, passenger unconscious.
common_errors: Using Mayday when Pan-Pan is appropriate
Pronouncing as 'pan-pan' like cooking pan (should be 'pahn-pahn')
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: PAHN-PAHN, with 'ah' sound like 'father', not like 'pan'.

vocabulary.definition: Total number of persons on the aircraft (passengers plus crew).
vocabulary.aviation_context: Required information during emergency declaration for rescue planning.
vocabulary.example_atc: ABC123, say souls on board and fuel remaining.
vocabulary.example_response: ABC123, 180 souls on board, 4 hours fuel remaining.
common_errors: Giving only passenger count (must include crew)

vocabulary.definition: Altitude expressed in hundreds of feet when set to standard pressure (1013.25 hPa / 29.92 inHg).
vocabulary.aviation_context: Used above transition altitude. FL350 = 35,000 feet.
vocabulary.example_atc: Emirates 502, climb and maintain flight level 350.
vocabulary.example_response: Climb and maintain flight level 350, Emirates 502.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: Say 'flight level three five zero', not 'three hundred fifty'.

vocabulary.definition: The direction in which the longitudinal axis of the aircraft is pointed, measured clockwise from north.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Given in three digits. 'Fly heading 270' means point the nose west.
vocabulary.example_atc: United 888, turn left heading 270.

vocabulary.definition: The lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Climbing through transition level, change altimeter to standard pressure.
vocabulary.example_atc: Swiss 456, passing transition level, set standard.
common_errors: Confusing transition level with transition altitude
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: tran-ZI-shun, stress on second syllable. The 's' sounds like 'zh'.

vocabulary.definition: Irregular motion of the atmosphere causing bumpy flight conditions.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Reported as light, moderate, severe, or extreme.
vocabulary.example_atc: All stations, pilot reports moderate turbulence at FL350 over ROMEO.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied, moderate turbulence FL350 over ROMEO, requesting FL370.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: TUR-byuh-luhns. Stress on first syllable. 'u' like 'bird'.

vocabulary.definition: The height above ground of the lowest layer of cloud covering more than half the sky.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Critical for approach minimums. 'Ceiling 500 broken' means clouds at 500 feet.
vocabulary.example_atc: Current weather: ceiling 800 overcast, visibility 2 miles in rain.
common_errors: Using wrong unit (should be feet AGL)

vocabulary.definition: The greatest distance at which prominent objects can be seen and identified.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Reported in meters (ICAO) or statute miles (US). Critical for approach minimums.
vocabulary.example_atc: Visibility 3000 meters in fog.
common_errors: Not converting between miles and meters
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: viz-uh-BIL-uh-tee. Stress on third syllable. Don't drop syllables.

vocabulary.definition: A sudden change in wind speed and/or direction over a short distance.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Dangerous during takeoff and landing. Requires immediate pilot action.
vocabulary.example_atc: Caution wind shear reported on final runway 27, plus 15 knots at 500 feet.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied wind shear, plus 15 knots at 500 feet, runway 27.
common_errors: Not specifying gain or loss (+/- knots)
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: WIND SHEER. The 'sh' is clear, the 'ear' rhymes with 'beer'.

vocabulary.definition: The accumulation of ice on the external surfaces of an aircraft.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Reported as light, moderate, or severe. Affects aircraft performance.
vocabulary.example_atc: Moderate icing reported in clouds between FL100 and FL150.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied moderate icing FL100 to FL150, requesting FL160.

vocabulary.definition: Meteorological Aerodrome Report - a standardized weather observation format.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Issued hourly, provides current conditions at an airport.
vocabulary.example_atc: METAR KJFK 251856Z 31008KT 10SM FEW040 BKN250 M02/M15 A3032
vocabulary.example_response: Understanding the METAR is essential for flight planning.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: MEE-tar or MET-ar. Either pronunciation acceptable.

vocabulary.definition: Large, towering clouds associated with thunderstorms, heavy rain, lightning, and severe turbulence.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Abbreviated CB. Must be avoided. Reported in METAR/TAF.
vocabulary.example_atc: CB reported along the route, deviation approved.
vocabulary.example_response: Requesting deviation right of track due CB.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: kyoo-myuh-loh-NIM-bus. Five syllables, stress on fourth.

vocabulary.definition: Hinged control surface on the trailing edge of each wing that controls roll.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Deflect oppositely: left aileron up, right aileron down = roll right.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: We have a jammed left aileron, difficulty controlling bank.
vocabulary.example_response: Understand jammed aileron, emergency services standing by.

vocabulary.definition: Hinged control surface on the horizontal stabilizer that controls pitch.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Deflecting up causes nose up pitch, down causes nose down.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: Experiencing elevator flutter at high speed.

vocabulary.definition: Hinged control surface on the vertical stabilizer that controls yaw.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Controls left/right movement of the nose around the vertical axis.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: Rudder is stuck in neutral position.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied stuck rudder, what are your intentions?

vocabulary.definition: The forward force produced by an aircraft's engines.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Overcomes drag. Measured in pounds or newtons.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: Reducing thrust due to engine vibration.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied reducing thrust, nearest suitable airport is 50 miles ahead.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: THRUST. Practice the 'th' sound - tongue between teeth.

vocabulary.definition: Relating to the system that uses fluid pressure to operate aircraft components.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Powers flight controls, landing gear, brakes in most jet aircraft.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: We have lost hydraulic system A, flight controls operating normally on system B.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied loss of hydraulic system A, advise if assistance required.
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: hy-DROH-lik. Stress on second syllable. 'H' is soft.

vocabulary.definition: Hinged surfaces on the trailing edge of the wings that increase lift and drag.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Extended for takeoff and landing to allow slower speeds.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: Flaps stuck at 15 degrees, unable to extend further.
vocabulary.example_response: Copied flaps stuck at 15, expect longer landing distance.
common_errors: Not reading back flap setting changes

vocabulary.definition: The landing gear; the wheels and supporting structure.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Extended for landing, retracted after takeoff.
vocabulary.example_atc: Singapore 21, confirm gear down.

vocabulary.definition: Auxiliary Power Unit - a small engine that provides electrical power and pneumatic pressure on the ground.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Used before main engine start and for ground operations.
vocabulary.example_atc: Pilot: APU unserviceable, request external power for engine start.
common_errors: Not knowing what APU stands for
Confusing APU with GPU (ground power unit)

vocabulary.definition: VHF Omnidirectional Range - a ground-based navigation aid.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Provides bearing information to/from the station.
vocabulary.example_atc: Proceed direct to ROMEO VOR.
common_errors: Pronouncing as 'vor' instead of spelling out
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: Spell out: V-O-R. Three separate letters.

vocabulary.definition: Instrument Landing System - precision approach aid providing lateral and vertical guidance.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Most accurate approach system. Consists of localizer and glideslope.
vocabulary.example_atc: Qatar 75, cleared ILS runway 27L approach.
common_errors: Pronouncing as 'ils' instead of spelling out
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: Spell out: I-L-S. Three separate letters.

vocabulary.definition: A predetermined geographical position used for route navigation.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Named with 5-letter pronounceable codes (e.g., ROMEO, BRAVO).
vocabulary.example_atc: Proceed direct waypoint MERIT.

vocabulary.definition: A defined path for aircraft ground movement connecting runways, ramps, and hangars.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Designated by letters (e.g., taxiway Alpha, Bravo).
vocabulary.example_atc: Qatar 101, taxi via Alpha, Bravo to runway 05.
vocabulary.example_response: Taxi via Alpha, Bravo to runway 05, Qatar 101.
common_errors: Not reading back the full taxi route

vocabulary.definition: A defined area intended for aircraft parking, loading, and unloading passengers and cargo.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Also called 'ramp' in the US. Where aircraft are serviced at gates.
vocabulary.example_atc: Emirates 507, taxi to apron stand 42.

vocabulary.definition: The procedure of pushing an aircraft backwards from the gate using a tug.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Requires ATC approval. First step in departure.
vocabulary.example_atc: Aeroflot 215, pushback approved, facing east.

vocabulary.definition: The removal of ice, frost, or snow from aircraft surfaces before flight.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Uses heated fluid. Different from anti-icing which prevents ice formation.
vocabulary.example_atc: Air Canada 881, proceed to de-icing pad.
vocabulary.example_response: Proceeding to de-icing pad, Air Canada 881.

vocabulary.definition: ATC position responsible for issuing departure clearances to pilots.
vocabulary.aviation_context: First ATC contact before flight. Provides route, altitude, squawk code.
vocabulary.example_atc: Uzbekistan Airways 653, contact clearance delivery on 121.9.

vocabulary.definition: To execute quickly; to climb or descend at a higher than normal rate.
vocabulary.aviation_context: ATC instruction when urgency or traffic separation requires faster action.
vocabulary.example_atc: Delta 234, expedite climb through FL200, traffic.

vocabulary.definition: To continue at the specified altitude, heading, or speed.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Used with altitude, heading, or speed assignments.
vocabulary.example_atc: British Airways 178, maintain FL350.

vocabulary.definition: ATC confirmation that the aircraft is identified on radar.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Pilot no longer needs to report position until radar contact lost.
vocabulary.example_atc: Thai 622, radar contact, 15 miles southwest of PAPA.
common_errors: Continuing position reports after radar contact

vocabulary.definition: Used to inform about anticipated clearances or conditions; not an actual clearance.
vocabulary.aviation_context: For planning only. Actual clearance will follow separately.
vocabulary.example_atc: JAL 006, expect FL380 in 10 minutes.

vocabulary.definition: To pass information to ATC at a specified point or condition.
vocabulary.aviation_context: ATC instruction to provide information at a specific time/place.
vocabulary.example_atc: SAS 937, report field in sight.
vocabulary.example_response: Wilco, SAS 937... SAS 937, field in sight.

vocabulary.definition: Other aircraft in the vicinity that may affect your flight.
vocabulary.aviation_context: ATC provides traffic information for awareness or separation.
vocabulary.example_atc: Qantas 94, traffic 12 o'clock, 5 miles, opposite direction, FL360, Boeing 777.
vocabulary.example_response: Looking for traffic, Qantas 94... Traffic in sight.

vocabulary.definition: To ask for something from ATC.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Proper way to ask for clearance changes, information, or assistance.
vocabulary.example_atc: Control, Iberia 341, request higher.
common_errors: Not specifying what is being requested

vocabulary.definition: Transponder code 7500 indicating aircraft hijacking.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Emergency code. Never squawk unless actual hijack situation.
vocabulary.example_atc: [Silent - aircraft squawks 7500]

vocabulary.definition: Transponder code 7600 indicating radio communication failure.
vocabulary.aviation_context: Used when unable to communicate by radio. Follow lost comm procedures.
vocabulary.example_atc: [Aircraft squawks 7600 - ATC provides light signals]
vocabulary.cis_pronunciation_tips: SEVEN SIX HUNDRED. Clear pronunciation essential.

listening_exercises.title: Standard IFR Departure Clearance
listening_exercises.transcript: Uzbekistan Airways 653, cleared to Tashkent via the Kennedy One departure, radar vectors to MERIT, then as filed. Climb and maintain 5,000, expect flight level 350 ten minutes after departure. Departure frequency 125.9. Squawk 4521.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Clear, slow pace. Pause slightly between each element. American ATC accent.

questions.question: What is the destination airport?
What is the initial altitude to maintain?
What is the squawk code?
What altitude should the pilot expect after 10 minutes?
questions.explanation: 'Expect flight level 350 ten minutes after departure'

teaching_points: Listen for 'cleared to' - this is the destination
'Climb and maintain' is the initial altitude
'Expect' is for planning only, not an actual clearance
Always write down the squawk code
listening_exercises.model_readback: Cleared to Tashkent, Kennedy One departure, radar vectors MERIT, then as filed. Climb maintain 5,000, expect FL350 ten minutes after departure. Departure 125.9, squawk 4521, Uzbekistan Airways 653.

listening_exercises.title: Taxi Instructions with Hold Short
listening_exercises.transcript: Aeroflot 215, taxi to runway 27 via Alpha, Bravo, hold short of runway 27L.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Normal pace. Emphasize 'hold short'. American accent.

questions.question: Which runway is the aircraft going to?
questions.explanation: 'Taxi to runway 27' is the destination runway

questions.question: What taxiways should the aircraft use?
Where must the aircraft stop?
questions.explanation: 'Hold short of runway 27L' - stop before crossing this runway

teaching_points: 'Hold short' is a critical instruction - always read back
The destination runway (27) is different from the hold short runway (27L)
Write down the taxi route - you may need to refer to it
listening_exercises.model_readback: Taxi to runway 27 via Alpha, Bravo, hold short runway 27L, Aeroflot 215.

listening_exercises.title: ATIS Information
listening_exercises.transcript: John F Kennedy International Airport, information Charlie. Time 1755 Zulu. Wind 310 at 15, gusts 22. Visibility 10 miles. Few clouds at 4,500, broken 8,000. Temperature 12, dewpoint 08. Altimeter 2992. ILS runway 31L approach in use. Landing runways 31L and 31R. Departing runway 31L. Advise on initial contact you have information Charlie.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Steady, measured pace as automated ATIS. Clear pronunciation of numbers.

questions.question: What is the ATIS information code?
What is the wind direction and speed?
What is the altimeter setting?
Which approach is in use?

teaching_points: Always note the ATIS code (Charlie, Delta, etc.)
Wind is given in degrees and knots
Altimeter setting must be set correctly for safe flight
You must advise ATC you have the ATIS information

listening_exercises.title: Traffic Information
listening_exercises.transcript: Emirates 502, traffic 2 o'clock, 8 miles, opposite direction, flight level 370, Airbus A380.

questions.question: Where is the traffic relative to the aircraft?
questions.explanation: Traffic 2 o'clock means slightly to the right

questions.question: How far away is the traffic?
What direction is the traffic moving?
questions.explanation: The traffic is flying opposite direction (towards you)

teaching_points: Clock positions: 12 o'clock is straight ahead, 3 o'clock is right, 9 o'clock is left
'Opposite direction' means the traffic is flying towards you
Flight level tells you if the traffic is above, below, or at your level

listening_exercises.title: Descent Clearance with Altimeter
listening_exercises.transcript: Speedbird 178, descend flight level 160. When passing flight level 180, QNH 1013.

questions.question: What flight level should the aircraft descend to?
When should the pilot set the altimeter?
What is the QNH setting?

teaching_points: FL180 is typically the transition level in Europe
QNH is given in hectopascals (millibars) outside the US
Set the altimeter at the transition level when descending
listening_exercises.model_readback: Descend FL160, QNH 1013 when passing FL180, Speedbird 178.

listening_exercises.title: Weather Deviation Request
listening_exercises.transcript: Singapore 21, deviation approved, left or right of track approved. Report when able direct to PAPA.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Professional tone. Pilot would have just requested deviation for weather.

questions.question: What is approved?
Where should the pilot report when able?

teaching_points: Weather deviations require ATC approval
ATC may approve both left and right options for flexibility
'Report when able' means tell ATC when you can return to route
listening_exercises.model_readback: Deviation approved left or right, will report when able direct PAPA, Singapore 21.

listening_exercises.title: Runway Change
listening_exercises.transcript: Virgin 407, due wind change, expect runway 09 instead of 27. Say your intentions.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: British regional accent. Professional but with urgency.

questions.question: Why is the runway changing?
What runway should the pilot now expect?
What does ATC want the pilot to do?

teaching_points: Runway changes affect approach briefing and fuel planning
'Say your intentions' requires a response about what you plan to do
Wind changes often lead to runway direction changes
listening_exercises.model_readback: Expect runway 09, we can accept, Virgin 407.

listening_exercises.title: Go-Around Instruction
listening_exercises.transcript: United 472, go around, I say again go around, traffic on the runway.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Urgent tone. Fast delivery. Repeated instruction.

questions.question: What instruction is given?
questions.explanation: 'Go around, I say again go around'

questions.question: Why is the go-around required?

teaching_points: 'I say again' indicates urgency - act immediately
Go-around is a critical instruction - comply first, ask questions later
Traffic on runway is a serious safety issue

listening_exercises.title: Engine Failure Report
listening_exercises.transcript: Mayday, Mayday, Mayday. Delta 456 heavy, engine failure, engine number 2. Position 50 miles northeast of ROMEO. Descending to flight level 300. Souls on board 287. Fuel remaining 3 hours. Request vectors to nearest suitable airport.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Calm but serious pilot voice. Clear pronunciation despite emergency.

questions.question: Which engine has failed?
How many souls are on board?
What is the pilot requesting?

teaching_points: Mayday format: say Mayday three times
Include: callsign, nature of emergency, position, intentions, souls, fuel
Stay calm and provide clear information

listening_exercises.title: Medical Emergency
listening_exercises.transcript: Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan. Air India 505, medical emergency. Passenger unconscious. Requesting priority handling and medical assistance on arrival. Position 200 miles south of DELHI. Estimating DELHI in 25 minutes.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Indian accent. Professional, calm despite urgency.

questions.question: What type of emergency call is this?
questions.explanation: 'Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan' is an urgency call, not immediately life-threatening to the aircraft

questions.question: What is the nature of the emergency?
How long until arrival at Delhi?

teaching_points: Pan-Pan is for urgency, Mayday is for life-threatening distress
Medical emergencies typically use Pan-Pan unless aircraft safety is affected
Request 'medical assistance on arrival' so airport can prepare
listening_exercises.model_readback: Air India 505, roger your Pan-Pan, medical assistance will be standing by.

listening_exercises.title: Wind Shear Warning
listening_exercises.transcript: All aircraft, wind shear alert. Loss of 20 knots at 300 feet on final runway 22. Previous aircraft reported go-around.
listening_exercises.audio_generation_notes: Broadcast to all aircraft. Urgent but professional.

questions.question: How much wind shear is reported?
questions.explanation: 'Loss of 20 knots' means airspeed decreases by 20 knots

questions.question: At what altitude was the wind shear encountered?
What did the previous aircraft do?

teaching_points: Wind shear 'loss' is dangerous - aircraft loses lift suddenly
'All aircraft' is a broadcast warning for everyone
If previous aircraft went around, conditions are serious
listening_exercises.model_readback: Copied wind shear, loss 20 knots at 300 feet, [callsign].

listening_exercises.title: Holding Instructions
listening_exercises.transcript: Lufthansa 450, hold at BIGGIN, inbound track 270, right-hand pattern, one minute legs. Expect approach time 1430.

questions.question: Where should the aircraft hold?
What is the direction of turns in the holding pattern?
What time should the pilot expect to begin approach?

teaching_points: Holding instructions include: fix, inbound track, direction, leg length
Standard holding is right-hand turns unless specified otherwise
Expect approach time helps with fuel planning
listening_exercises.model_readback: Hold BIGGIN, inbound 270, right-hand, one minute legs, expect approach 1430, Lufthansa 450.

speaking_scenarios.title: IFR Clearance Readback
speaking_scenarios.setup: You are the pilot of flight HY653, an Uzbekistan Airways flight at Tashkent. You have received your IFR clearance and must read it back.
speaking_scenarios.atc_prompt_text: Uzbekistan Airways 653, cleared to Moscow via the TASHKENT ONE departure, flight planned route. Climb and maintain 6,000, expect flight level 390 ten minutes after departure. Departure frequency 121.7. Squawk 3241.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Cleared to Moscow, TASHKENT ONE departure, flight planned route. Climb maintain 6,000, expect flight level 390 ten minutes after departure. Departure 121.7, squawk 3241, Uzbekistan Airways 653.

scoring_rubric.vocabulary: Uses correct aviation terms: cleared, maintain, departure, squawk
scoring_rubric.pronunciation: Clear pronunciation of numbers and names

common_cis_errors: Saying 'flight level three nine zero' instead of 'flight level three niner zero'
Adding unnecessary words like 'I am cleared' instead of just 'cleared'

speaking_scenarios.title: Position Report
speaking_scenarios.setup: You are flying at FL350 and have just passed waypoint ROMEO. You need to make a position report to ATC.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Air Astana 714, position ROMEO at 1435, flight level 350, estimating BRAVO at 1502, next CHARLIE.
common_cis_errors: Forgetting to include time over position

speaking_scenarios.title: Request Weather Deviation
speaking_scenarios.setup: You are flying at FL380 and see thunderstorms ahead on your weather radar. You need to request a deviation.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Tokyo Control, Korean Air 085, position 50 miles south of SIERRA. Request deviation 30 miles right of track due weather.

scoring_rubric.structure: Request format is clear and complete

common_cis_errors: Saying 'because of weather' instead of 'due weather'

speaking_scenarios.title: Declaring Fuel Emergency
speaking_scenarios.setup: You are 100 miles from destination but have been holding for 45 minutes due to weather. Your fuel is now minimum. You must declare an emergency.
expected_elements: Mayday or Pan-Pan (Pan-Pan is appropriate for minimum fuel)
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan. Thai 622, minimum fuel emergency. Position 100 miles east of destination. Fuel remaining 45 minutes. 210 souls on board. Request immediate approach and priority landing.
common_cis_errors: Using Mayday when Pan-Pan is appropriate
Speaking too fast due to stress

speaking_scenarios.title: Engine Fire Declaration
speaking_scenarios.setup: You have just received an engine fire warning on your number 2 engine. You must declare an emergency and request return to departure airport.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Mayday, Mayday, Mayday. Emirates 507, engine fire, engine number 2. Position 30 miles east of Dubai, flight level 280. Shutting down engine 2. Request immediate return to Dubai. 312 souls on board, 5 hours fuel remaining.

speaking_scenarios.title: Go-Around Announcement
speaking_scenarios.setup: You are on final approach but the runway is not clear. You must execute a go-around and advise ATC.

scoring_rubric.vocabulary: Uses 'going around' not 'I am going around'

common_cis_errors: Saying 'I am going around' instead of 'going around'

speaking_scenarios.title: Unable to Comply
speaking_scenarios.setup: ATC has instructed you to descend to FL250, but you cannot comply because of weather at that altitude.
speaking_scenarios.atc_prompt_text: Singapore 381, descend and maintain flight level 250.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Unable FL250, weather. Request maintain FL300 or higher, Singapore 381.

speaking_scenarios.title: Requesting Higher Altitude
speaking_scenarios.setup: You are cruising at FL350 but experiencing moderate turbulence. You want to request a higher altitude.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Mumbai Control, Qatar 75, moderate turbulence at FL350. Request climb to FL390.

speaking_scenarios.title: Radio Check
speaking_scenarios.setup: You have just changed frequency and need to confirm your radio is working.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: London Control, Uzbekistan Airways 653, radio check.

speaking_scenarios.title: Medical Emergency - Passenger
speaking_scenarios.setup: A passenger has collapsed and is unresponsive. The cabin crew has requested you divert to the nearest airport for medical assistance.
speaking_scenarios.sample_response: Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan, Pan-Pan. ABC123, medical emergency. Passenger unconscious, not breathing. Request immediate divert to nearest suitable airport. Require medical assistance on arrival. 180 souls on board, 4 hours fuel remaining.

W.cis_tip: WISS-kee, start with W not V

common_cis_pronunciation_errors.explanation: Russian has no TH sound. In aviation, 'three' is pronounced 'tree' which actually helps!
Russian W sounds like V. Practice: lips round for W, teeth touch lip for V.
Russian doesn't distinguish vowel length. Can change word meaning.
English stress patterns differ from Russian. Stress wrong syllable = hard to understand.
Russian devoices final consonants. In English this changes meaning.
H is often dropped or made too guttural. Should be soft breath.
